Automatic Tabs Distill/Rmarkdown

Source: vignettes/automatic_tabs.Rmd
automatic_tabs.Rmd

What are tabs? ğŸ¤”

âœï¸ A tab is a design pattern where content is separated into different panes, and each pane is viewable one at a time.

How to generate tabs? ğŸ—‚ï¸

ğŸ”¹ In order to generate the tabs above, the following chunks were necessary:

ğŸ” As it can be seen, this is not so difficult. However, what if we wanted to generate 16 tabs instead of 4?

Using a tidy approach, an automatic tab generation ğŸ§™ can be performed by nesting the objects to include in each tab. Letâ€™s see an example.

Data ğŸ“Š

For this example, time series data from the Argentine monthly economic activity estimator (EMAE) is used. This data is available in the sknifedatar package ğŸ“¦.

Libraries ğŸ“š

#devtools::install_github("rafzamb/sknifedatar")
library(sknifedatar)

#devtools::install_github("gadenbuie/xaringanExtra")
library(xaringanExtra)

library(lubridate)
library(timetk)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(purrr)
emae <- sknifedatar::emae_series

Nested dataframes ğŸ“‚

ğŸ”¹ The first step is to generate a nested data frame. It includes a row per economic sector.

nest_data <- emae %>%
  nest(nested_column = -sector)

nest_data
## # A tibble: 16 x 2
##    sector                           nested_column     
##    <chr>                            <list>            
##  1 Comercio                         <tibble [202 Ã— 2]>
##  2 EnseÃ±anza                        <tibble [202 Ã— 2]>

ğŸ‘€ To better understand the format of nest_data, the "nested_column" variable is disaggregated below. By clicking on each sector, it can be seen that ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ each nested column includes data for the series of the selected sector. In the first row, data corresponds to the monthly activity estimator from 2004-01-01 to 2020-10-01 for the â€˜Commerceâ€™ sector.

Time series plots ğŸŒ 

ğŸ‘‰ The evolution of each series can be observed by using a tab for each sector. This allows the visualization to be much clearer ğŸ™Œ, allowing the reader to focus on each series, without having to view multiple plots of the same type.

nest_data <- 
  nest_data %>%
  mutate(ts_plots = map(nested_column, 
                        ~ plot_time_series(.data = .x,
                                           .date_var = date,
                                           .value = value,
                                           .color_var = year(date),
                                           .interactive = FALSE,
                                           .line_size = 1, 
                                           .smooth_color = 'lightgrey',
                                           .smooth_size = 0.1,
                                           .legend_show = FALSE
                                          )))
nest_data
## # A tibble: 16 x 3
##    sector                           nested_column      ts_plots
##    <chr>                            <list>             <list>  
##  1 Comercio                         <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  2 EnseÃ±anza                        <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  3 AdministraciÃ³n pÃºblica           <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  4 Transporte y comunicaciones      <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  5 Servicios sociales/Salud         <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  6 Impuestos netos                  <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  7 Sector financiero                <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
##  8 MinerÃ­a                          <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>

## 15 Industria manufacturera          <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>    
## 16 ConstrucciÃ³n                     <tibble [202 Ã— 2]> <gg>

ğŸ“½ First, a column called â€œts_plotsâ€ is added, where we store the visualizations of the time series. For this we apply the function â€œplot_time_seriesâ€ on each series stored in the column â€œnested_columnâ€ through the function "map". The function plot_time_series is included on the timetk package ğŸ“¦. One of the series is displayed below.Notice that we are using lubridate package to add different colors for each year. This allows us to infer if seasonality is present in each time series, although we will analyse this later on this article.

nest_data %>% pluck("ts_plots",1)

Perfect, but â€¦ if we wanted to graph all the time series, how could we do it? ğŸ¤”

The â€œautomagic_tabsâ€ function of the sknifedatar package was created for this. It receives 3 main arguments:

  • input_data: The nested dataframe that we have created ğŸ’¾, in our case, the â€œnest_dataâ€ object.

  • panel_name: The name of the column of the nested dataframe where the series names are, these names will be the titles of each tabs ğŸ“. In our case, â€œsectorâ€.

  • .output: The name of the column of the nested dataframe that stores the graphs to be displayed ğŸ“ˆ. In our case, â€œts_plotsâ€.

ğŸ›  Additional arguments: you can specify the width of the set of panels in â€œ.layoutâ€, ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ in addition to being able to specify all the parameters available on rmarkdown chunks ğŸ™Œ (fig.align, fig.width, â€¦)

ğŸ”¹ Letâ€™s see the application below, first we invoke the â€œuse_panelset" function from the xaringanExtra package ğŸ“¦ and then theâ€automagic_tabs" function.

xaringanExtra::use_panelset()
`r automagic_tabs(input_data = nest_data, panel_name = "sector", .output = "ts_plots",
                  .layout = "l-page", fig.heigth=1, fig.width=10)`

âš  Note something important, ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ğŸ‘‰ the function does not run in a chunk, it is invoked â€œinlineâ€ (or an r function between apostrophes) within the Rmarkdown document. Below is the complete code:

#---
#title: "automagic_tabs"
#author: "sknifedatar"
#output: html_document
#---
#
#```{r}
#library(sknifedatar)
#library(timetk)
#```
#
#```{r}
#emae <- sknifedatar::emae_series 
#
#nest_data <- emae %>%
#  nest(nested_column = -sector) %>% 
#  mutate(ts_plots = map(nested_column, 
#                        ~ plot_time_series(.data = .x,
#                                           .date_var = date,
#                                           .value = value,
#                                           .interactive = FALSE,
#                                           .line_size = 0.15)
#                         ))
#```
#
#```{r}
#xaringanExtra::use_panelset()
#```
#
#`r automagic_tabs(input_data = nest_data, panel_name = "sector", .output = "ts_plots")`

ğŸ”¹ Copy the code above, paste it into a new Rmarkdown file, and hit knit the document to get the tabs.
